item.title: Florida Refinance Credit Requirements: How Middle Credit Scores Affect Your Options
item.description:
Your credit score determines more than just approval. It affects your rate, your available programs, and whether refinancing is even worth it. Here’s how Florida lenders actually use your credit when reviewing refinance applications.

Why Lenders Focus on Your Middle Score

You have three credit scores (Experian, Equifax, TransUnion). Lenders pull all three and use the middle score.

Example:

  • Experian: 720
  • Equifax: 685
  • TransUnion: 705

Your middle score is 705—that’s what lenders use for qualification and pricing.

item.title: How Credit Scores Affect Florida Mortgage Rates: Tiers, Pricing, and Optimization
item.description:
A 780 credit score gets 6.50%. A 680 credit score gets 7.25%. Same borrower, same down payment, same property—0.75% difference just from credit. Here’s how credit scores affect Florida mortgage rates and what you can do about it.

Why Credit Scores Affect Rates

Lenders price risk. Lower credit score = higher risk of default = higher interest rate to compensate.

It’s not personal—it’s actuarial. Statistically, borrowers with 640 credit default more often than borrowers with 740 credit. Lenders charge more to offset that risk.
